preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-6.5 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with full sun receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start Cabbage seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-05-10 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.5 inches deep with 15 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-05-10 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water Cabbage deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect Cabbage weekly for common zone 4a-6a pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting Cabbage approximately 70 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Cabbage at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

plant_groupings.spacing_notes: Plant Cabbage and Eggplant in rows, with Cabbage on the north side to avoid shading Kale
Plant Kale along the south border of the garden for maximum sunlight

general_tips: Choose a sunny spot with well-draining soil for your garden, as both cabbage and eggplant require full sun to produce well.
In Moncton's cool climate, start seedlings indoors 4-6 weeks before the last frost date (around May 15th) to give them a head start on the growing season.
Kale is a hardy crop that can tolerate light frosts, but cabbage and eggplant are more sensitive. Use row covers or bring potted plants under cover if there's a risk of frost.
Soil temperature affects germination rates - wait until soil has warmed up to at least 7°C (45°F) before planting cool-season crops like kale and cabbage.
Eggplant is a warm-season crop that thrives in temperatures above 18°C (65°F). Plant it after the last frost date, when the soil has warmed up.
Keep your garden consistently watered, but avoid overwatering which can lead to root rot and other issues. Aim for about 2-3 inches of rainfall or irrigation per week.
Monitor for pests like aphids, slugs, and snails that can damage your crops. Use organic pest control methods whenever possible to maintain a healthy garden ecosystem.
